results.title: The Beast must die
results.creator_credit: Paul Annett, Milton Subotsky, Max J Rosenberg and Amicus Productions
results.brief_description: A wealthy and ambitious hunter gathers several guests to his expansive country estate with the intention of revealing that one is a werewolf. Initially baffled by their host’s objective, the visitors soon become terrified that one among them may be a killer beast. Resembling an Agatha Christie mystery, this is a promising set-up, but offers little in the way of clues or intrigue, despite the invitation for audience participation to deduce the killer. The film features Christopher Lee as a lycanthrope expert, and there are 1970s blaxploitation overtones with Calvin Lockhart in the lead role. Also known as “Black werewolf”.

results.title: The Battlers
results.creator_credit: George Ogilvie, Gus Howard and South Australian Film Corporation
results.brief_description: Based on the novel of the same name by Kylie Tennant this made for television mini-series is set in Australia during the Great Depression. It focuses on the friendship between two ‘battlers’, Dancy, an orphan who has spent most of her life on the streets and Snow, a taciturn man on the rebound from a failed marriage. Forced to travel the country in search of work, like many working-class Australians of the time, and surviving mainly on dole book rations, their lives are full of hardship and deprivation, but the comradeship they develop on the road also brings them many moments of comfort and happiness. Cast includes Audine Lieth, Marcus Graham, Anne Phelan, Gary Sweet and Jacqueline McKenzie.

results.title: The Bear
results.creator_credit: Jean-Jacques Annaud, Claude Berri, Price Entertainment and Renn Productions
results.brief_description: A captivating and unusual film about a bear cub who is orphaned and forced to fend for itself until it finds a new protector in a giant Kodiak - the tempting target for a pair of hunters. Filmed with utmost respect for animals and a real sense of nature’s magnificence in the breathtaking mountain lands of British Columbia. Based on the novel “The grizzly king” by James Oliver Curwood.

results.title: The Beachcomber = Vessel of wrath
results.creator_credit: Erich Pommer and Mayflower Pictures Corporation
results.brief_description: Ginger Ted is a dissolute beachcomber, a drunken remittance man (the ‘black sheep’ of an upper class English family being paid to stay away) residing on an island in the Archipelagos. Ted revels in the squalor there, enjoying an endless supply of liquor and the charms of a local girl. A Dutch missionary’s pious sister, Martha Jones, takes an exceptional dislike to Ted, proclaiming him a corrupting influence. Her attitude toward him shifts however when the two are briefly stranded on an island. Shortly afterwards Martha heads off to a remote community where she is determined to counteract an outbreak of cholera. But her efforts are misguided; whilst distributing an antidote she is riled by the natives’ rituals and swiftly earns their wrath. Ted manages to protect her and the pair, inevitably, are romantically united. Laughton succeeds well here with his portrayal of Ted, a slovenly drunkard whose attitude toward the local populace is far more tolerant than the parochial and condescending Martha. Cast also includes Elsa Lanchester and Robert Newton. Based on the tale “Vessel of wrath” by W. Somerset Maugham.

results.title: The Battle of Algiers [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Gillo Pontecorvo, Saadi Yacef and Antonio Musu
results.brief_description: Pontecorvo’s passionate and devastating study of terrorism builds a tight narrative around the reconstruction of the main political events in Algiers between 1954-57: the rise of the nationalist movement led by the Algerian Liberation Front (F. L. N.), its crushing defeat by the French in 1957 and the resurgence 3 years later of Arab nationalism with led to Algerian independence in 1962. The film holds both a specific and a universal interest; first in the observation of the method of starting - and crushing a revolutionary movement and second in the wider implications behind both French and Algerian tactics and the implicit debate on the legtimacy of the steps taken to achieve an end. In French and Arabic with English sub-titles.

results.title: The Beach: a river of sand
results.creator_credit: Warren Brown, Stanley Croner and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description: Shows by an analysis of currents produced by waves and calculations of the accumulation and depletion of sand, that the most pronounced movement of sand is along the seashore. Also illustrates effects of breakwaters and other works.

results.title: The Baymen
results.creator_credit: Rex Tasker, Peter Jones and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Baymen, no matter where they go, remain above all else Newfoundlanders. They were born to the sea, to a place in the life of their cliffside village, but many of the younger generation are now looking to the city for their future. This film shows the feelings of generation after generation of four families who have earned their living by gathering fish for over 400 years. How will the big industries now affect the lives of the Baymen? It follows a Bayman’s family to St. John’s (Vancouver Island), showing what such a change means to father, daughter and grandfather. Camera: Hector J. Lemieux.

results.title: The Battleship Potemkin [DVD]
results.brief_description: Originally made to celebrate the 20th anniversary of the unsuccessful 1905 Russian Revolution, this film portrays the mutiny aboard the Russian battleship Potemkin and the role of the sailors and citizens of the Port of Odessa in the abortive revolution of 1905. It brought to the attention of the world the theories of Sergei Eisenstein, his emphasis on montage and his stress on the individual as protagonist.

results.title: The Battle of Huangqiao = Huang Qiao Jue Zhan
results.creator_credit: Shen Bingfeng, Yang Zhaoren and August First Film Studio
results.brief_description:
This film depicts the battle of Huangqiao (or: Huang Bridge) between the Chinese Communist Party and the KMT during the anti-Japanese war. In 1940, the New Route 4 Army decided to set up an anti-Japanese base in the Subei area (Jiangsu province), but the KMT sent troops 10 times more than the New Route 4 Army in order to eliminate it. The first confrontation was in Taizhou, where two chief KMT commanders in Taizhou were persuaded by CCP’s well-known general Chen Yi to join the anti-Japanese force. Chen Yi later attacked another troop of KMT and caught its leader Lin Taiyuan alive. However, Chen Yi released Lin and persuaded him again. The vice general commander of the Sulu area, Han Deqin did not want to give up and decided to have a battle with Chen’s troops at Huang Bridge. Led by Chen Yi and Su Yu, the New Route 4 Army defeated the KMT troops ten times of its size. The battle eliminated the KMT hardliners’ hope to destroy the anti-Japanese alliance between CCP and KMT, and was crucial for the foundation of the Subei anti-Japanese base.

Huangqiao battle is a key battle for the New Route 4 Army of the CCP in the early stage of the anti-Japanese war. Recently, it has attracted a renewed interest from the August First Film Studio to make a documentary film about the battle. This documentary project is supported by the State Administration of Radio, Film and Television, and it will be produced digitally. This kind of military films are normally state-sponsored and made for the purpose of patriotic education in China. (3 stars - Yuxing Zhou; December 16, 2010)

results.title: The Battle for Bowen Hills
results.creator_credit: Garry Lane, Peter Gray and Crowsfoot Films
results.brief_description: The story of Brisbane working class residents’ protracted struggle to defend their homes against the inner city freeway proposals of the Queensland Government. This film was made for community groups under a similar threat and for those interested in multinational development and the political economy of transport. Narrated by Geraldine Willisee. (Also includes ex-Queensland Senator Russ Hinze).
